TRAHSGRIPr OF 126th REGULAR 'MEETING OF THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS HELD IN BOARD ROOM ON WEDl'JESDAY MARCH 17, 1948, at 11:00 a.m.
GHAIR1JiAN : Viill the meeting come to order, please. Dr. Wilson, Mr. McFarlane's
Alternate, from Australia, is with us this morning. Will you stand up
and take a bow, Dr. Wilson? What kind of Doctor is that? Is tllat a
Doctor of Economics, or a real doctor, or What?
SUNDARES.AN : Not of human diseases.
CHAIRMAN: You have the minutes of the 125th Regular Meeting. Are there any comments?
If not, I will declare them approved. Item No. 2 on the agenda is a report
on the loan application of Chile. I want to tell you a little about that,
why I put it on the agenda, and in the end why I am taking it off for this
morning. As you know, I contemplate taking a trip to Latin America, South
America particularly, commencing the first of the month, to be gone about
a month. I am going first to the Republic of Colombia, shall be there just a little after the commencement of the Bogota Conference and shall
then spend a few days in Bogota am elsewhere in Colombia. I then go on
to Ecuador, Peru, Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Venezuela, and home. I am not going down to attend the Bogota Conference in any sense as
a participant. My invitation in fact is from the Republic of Colombia and
not from any official of the Conference. I do hope, however, to take advantage of the opportunity "which will be afforded to meet in one spot
before I proceed on my way a number of the Finance Ministers and others
who are interested in the economic development of Latin America. Being
away for that length of time, I would have liked to have been able to clear
up some of our proposed Latin American financing. It would be a little
embarrassing to turn up in Santiago the day the Directors approve a loan
- 759 -  (
to Chile, or the day I arrive in Bogota. That is an embarrassment, but
not fundamental. I made inquiries to find out where we stood on two of
these loans, particularly to determine Whether we could not take action
in principle on these loans some time not in too close juxtaposition on
my trip. It was indicated to me that we were probably close enough to
justify that action and it would be a comfort to me to go off' with one or
possibly two of those loans on the track, subject to further completion in
due course as papers could be drawn up and details worked out. I am not
entirely sure, however, that we are at a point, although I think we are
fairly close, where that type of action can be taken. Rather than be
uncertain about it I suggest that we postpone consideration of the report
on Chile at ttlis time and be prepared to be able to discuss it next week,
unless intervening circumstances make it clear that that would not be
adVisable, or perhaps hold ourselves available for a special meeting some
time before next week. Next week's meeting, as you know, has been ante-
dated from l'fednesday to Tuesday, due to the fact that a number of officials
are corning to visit the Bank from the New England area. It would be a
matter of greater convenience if we could have the meeting on Tuesday
rather than Wednesday, because I am anxious that these gentlemen should
meet as many of the Executive Directors as possible. It would probably be easier to ~~e appointments throughout the day if we had the Directors'
Meeting the day before. If "..'e can arrive at a point where we feel that
this action in respect of Chile would be desirable, we would call a special
meeting, though I do not know that we can have one, on account of suggest-
ions already made to me by some of the directors as to their commitments
towards the end of the ".eek. At any rate, we will postpone it today. I
- 760 - C} .MAN: want to say that the report that you have before you is really no more
at this time than a draft report. We may make some corrections in it.
The substance probably will remain the same, but there may be additions
and corrections we will want to make. If so, we will substitute pages
before the next meeting, when we will consider the report. There is also
in that report a number of matters relating to the Chilean financial
Situation, which of course are confidential. I hope they will be treated
as such. Is there anything else? Did I cover that situation fully?
IlLANES: Yes, Mr. Chairman; the only point I would like to make is that there be
added after the first paragraph, of the report, a memorandum we sent to
you on June 6, 1947 concerning the points that are mentioned in the first paragraph under "History of the Negotiations ll â€¢ CoW of that memorandum
I will give to the Secretary in order that it can be added to the Report.
CHA.lRMAN: I meant to make reference to that.
The other loan vmich was pretty close to consideration by the Board was
the Brazilian loan. There, however, are also some complications which
I think would make it unwise for us to consider it now, much as vre might
like to. I might suggest at this time though, ~~thout any further dis-
cussion, because I do not know enough to report to the Board facts to
justify a discussion, that the fundamental problem there is going to be
that we shall have to determine vmat our attitude in regard to Brazil will
be in the event that Brazil's situation with the Fund is not cleared up.
Now so much for Item 1';0. 2. I have nothing else on the formal agenda. I
thought I might mention Professor Varvaressos t report and tell you that
the Loan andR.esearch Department people are putting together comments on
that report and I hope to have that to you in due time if the Directors
would like it and have a discussion about that report and those comments.
- 161 - HDPPENOT: Mr. Chairman, I must tell you quite frankly that I do not know if I am entitled or qualified as a member of the Board to discuss or even to hear
about Pro fessor Varvaressos t report. I read it carefully yesterday, but
there is a very large number of personal opinions on England and on France
that I will not be able to diSCUSS, such as on the political situation,
history of the country, and so forth. Matters have been discussed at the
Sixteen Nations t Meeting that may have been discussed here when we went
into the French Loan. Really I do not feel able to discuss ~t and I do
not feel entitled to.
CHAIRMAN: I certainly am not going to require anybody to discuss anytMng they do
not want to discuss, and I am not putting it fOITfard as any sort of
official item on the agenda. I think the whole question of European re-
covery is something in which the Board is vitally interested and I would
think that if we could not discuss that in the Board we would scarcely be
doing our duty. VIe have already had discussions on European Recovery
problems and perhaps it vrould be unwise, inappropriate or ineffective to
discuss it as an item of an agenda, but I wonder 'whether it could not be
considered as a continuation of some of the informal meetings which we
have had on general world recovery problems. Don't you think that is the way to do it?
lillNRO: I have not yet had the opportunity of studying it closely. I have glanced
through i t and my feelings are that I am in sympathy with my French
colleague. I do rather question how embarrassing it might be for certain
members. Certain questions and opinions brought into the thing may be
inappropriate for us to discuss as a Board when it will not have a direct
bearing on any course of action we might adopt. I agree that it is a
valuable report and controversial, as many valuable things are. I agree
however, that we might wish the whole subject discussed sooner or later.
- 762 -  I must say I had never tllOUght of this thing. I get at first blush that
there mie;ht be some hesital1cy to discuss a report of this nature. Let me
talk off the cuff. I do feel in some form or other this Board ought to
feel free from all its international representation to discuss frankly
what conditions are throughout the world, vd.thout having it spread on the
record. The political views affect the economic and the economic views
aIfect the political. If we can only discuss certain s.exless types of
report we will not be getting and we vall not have the general freedom ani
objectivity that I think and organization of this type ought to have.
This is my first reaction.
BEYEN: I think that i t would be regrettable i f the fact that Professor Varvaressos
has uttered his opinions on political matters with frankness of view would
bar us from discussion of the economic aspects of his report. I think it
is our duty to do so and I lIould very much like to do it for various
reasons. First, I think we could have, as promised, a report from the
Research Department on it, but, quite apart from the political angles,
there are various stater:Jents of economic character. Many of them are
economic in character and wholesome, but some of them I think are at least
open to doubt. I think ,{fe could be given an opportunity to discuss those
angles at any rate.
BARANSKI: I am absolutely impartial and objective because I have not yet read it.
So I cannot say what are either the advantages or disadvantages of the
discussion, but if the matter is controversial it is better to have a
discussion and stress the controversial points. Otherwise we will give
the impression, even with the comments of the Research and of the Loan
Departments, that Prr)fessor Varva~ssos is right.
CH}l.l RMAN : Anybody else?
- 763 - CF U:I!AH: Let me go on and finish by saying that the representatives of the insurance (CL.dt'd) companies, according to IlliY schedule, will be here on March 24th from
Massachusetts, and on the 26th from the Commonwealth of Virginia. Mr. 1iachado?
MACHADO: This is st. Patrick's Day, and Saint Patrick brought to Ireland a lot of
courage and faith and music and poetry. A year ago it brought us McCloy.
Since we have survived a year under McCloy we ought to recognize that fact
and go on record with our appreciation of our good association with him,
and the expectation that he will carry us forward to great accomplishments.
CEAI 'Th'lAN : I am ver.r touched by that. Certainly I am glad that St. Patrick brought
me here. I look back on this year with a great deal of satisfaction. I
shall long remember that first meetLTlg I had with the Board when I came,
after the stress and strain of many newspaper comments. It was a very
awh'''ward time for us all. He have gotten some roots down this year. I
hope that the next year vdll find deeper and finner roots embedded in the
soil. I am absolutely confident that they will be so embedded, and am the
more certain in my feeling about that by reason of the fact that I now
know so thoroughly that the Board of Directors have the objectives of the
Bank deeply rooted in their own convictions and have shO\m such rnagnificent
cooperation with the manageJrent in conducting this institution. It has
been a very pleasant association indeed. Although the next year looks
from this particular point as being another one of stress and strain, we
can look forward so far as the Bank is concerned, with confidence in the
knowledge that we have a good and loyal institution to cope .dth the
difficult problems that are bound to arise. (APPLAUSE)
- 764 - cr 1MAN: I understand there is a radio set up here so that anyone who 'wants to (CtJtlt1d) can listen to the President's speech at 12:30. I think the connection is good. The meeting is closed.
ADJOURNED 11 :25 a.m.
Sir Gordon, you had something to say.
1.'1JNRO: Thank you very much. I want to make at the outset, a few remarks not in
my capacity as Executive Director of this Bank. I am speaking merely as
a Scotsman on st. Patric}c's Day, I suppose, and since I am not speaking
as a Director of this Board, perhaps it would be appropriate if I rose for this occasion. I have been charged, Mr. President and Directors,
with a most pleasant du~, by the Governor of the Bank of Eneland, Lord
Catto, and the Court of the Bank of England. They heard that the Bank
bad started a Luncheon Room, similar to their own, and they are very
anxious to give some small expression of their friendliness and esteem,
by making some token gift to the President and Directors of this Bank,
ri.hich they hoped would be used in the Luncheon Room. This is the small
gift they wanted to f,ive. They send this wooden box from the Bank of England. They were any~ous to make the presentation a personal one and
wished to give some small token. This box is made from one of the piles
on which the Bank of England was built in 1797. They hope very much it
vnll be welcomed, and that you vall appreciate it. I have a letter from
the Governor, which I would like, if I may, Mr. President, to read:
"Dear Mr. President, It has come to my knowledge that you and your
colleagues are starting a Luncheon Room rather on the lines of our own.
I am pleased to hear this becaus~ I am sure that it will prove a pleasant
and informal way of cementing your contacts with visitors from Central
- 765 - ML_._..O: Banks and others from allover the world. We are, as you know, always (Cont'd) happy to see our friends at our luncheon table and we have already had
the pleasure of so entertaining representatives of the International Bank.
As a token of our good wishes I am sending you on behal,f of my
colleagues and myself one of the cigarette boxes which were made from the
piles on which the Bank was built in 1797. I hope that you will use it
at your luncheon table and that it will remind you of the interest and
sympathy which the Old Lady bears toward your Institution.
I am, Dear Mr. President,
Yours Sincerely,
CATTO II
On behalf of the Governor, I would like to hand this over as a small
token of esteem and affection.
CiiAIRMAN : This is a very warming, and highly appreciated gift we have received from
the Mother of Banks, and it )'.rill, I am sure, gi ve us inspiration as we
are diJling at our board, to have the cigarettes passed from this box. The
thoughtfulness of Lord Catto, and of the Governor and Court of the Bank of
England is deeply appreciated, and I hope that we will have an occasion, or many occasions, on which we' can welcome them to sit at our board when
they visit this country. Thank you very much indeed.
